title: Acute microplastic exposure raises stress response and suppresses detoxification and immune capacities in the scleractinian coral Pocillopora damicornis

affiliation.laboratory: Key Laboratory of Tropical Biological Resources of Ministry of Education
Key Laboratory of Tropical Biological Resources of Ministry of Education
Key Laboratory of Tropical Biological Resources of Ministry of Education
Key Laboratory of Tropical Biological Resources of Ministry of Education

abstract: Acute microplastic exposure raises stress response and suppresses detoxification and immune capacities in the scleractinian coral

abstract.text: Acute microplastic exposure raises stress response and suppresses detoxification and immune capacities in the scleractinian coral

body_text.text: Scleractinian corals live in shallow seas with low nutrient and high illumination conditions, depending on intracellular symbiosis with zooxanthellae (Dubinsky and Jokiel, 1994) . In the mutualistic symbiosis, corals provide inorganic nutrients and carbon dioxide for the photosynthetic zooxanthellae, while zooxanthellae supply M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT corals with indispensable organic nutrients and oxygen (Muller-Parker et al., 2015) .
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: However, the intricate coral-zooxanthella symbiosis is sensitive to changes in the environment, and can collapse due to elevated seawater temperatures and environmental pollution (Schlöder and D'Croz, 2004) . Therefore, scleractinian corals have experienced frequent and severe degradation over the past decades (Vidal-Dupiol et al., 2011) .
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Microplastics (particle diameters < 1 mm) are a type of emerging pollutants in marine ecosystems, and have been considered a serious hazard to marine organisms (Ogonowski et al., 2018) . Microplastics can be ingested by a wide range of marine species ranging from zooplankton to bivalves, crustaceans, and fish, and hence enter into the marine food chain (Devriese et al., 2015; Sun et al., 2017; Tanaka and Takada, 2016; Van Cauwenberghe and Janssen, 2014) . Because these ingested microplastics are not degradable for most marine organisms, the microplastics can accumulate and cause adverse effects on the organisms through the blockage of alimentary tract (Wright et al., 2013) . Microplastics can also form hetero-aggregates with marine phytoplankton and repress their growth, photosynthesis, and sinking (Long et al., 2015; Long et al., 2017) . Furthermore, marine microplastics are a complex cocktail of polymers, residual monomers, and chemical additives, as they can absorb organic matter and chemical contaminants or have the potential to accumulate bacteria (Zhang et al., 2017) . Adsorbed chemical substances of small molecular sizes can be transferred directly into the cells and tissues, and have severe toxic effects on the consumer organisms (Teuten et al., 2009) . Several chemicals associated with the M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT microplastics function as environmental hormones to activate signal transduction pathways in target tissues, and modulate physiological activities of marine organisms (Panti et al., 2015) . For example, it has been reported that microplastics induced oxidative stress and triggered the MAPK/Nrf2 pathway in the marine copepod Paracyclopina nana and rotifer Brachionus koreanus (Jeong et al., 2017; Jeong et al., 2016) . Microplastic debris has also been observed in the coral reef ecosystem, and some studies have noted the impact of microplastics on scleractinian corals (Allen et al., 2017; Hall et al., 2015; Reichert et al., 2018) . Microplastic pollution has been detected in a few coral reef ecosystems worldwide, such as South China Sea and Great Barrier Reef (Reisser et al., 2013; Zhao et al., 2015) . There have been limited studies examining the effects of microplastic exposure on corals, although recent studies have shown that microplastic plastics can be ingested in culture experiments of corals such as Dipsastrea pallida and wrapped in mesenterial tissue within the coral gut cavity (Hall et al., 2015) . It has been also reported that the microplastic consumption is driven by chemoreception in Astrangia poculata (Allen et al., 2017) . Furthermore, different coral species can respond differently to microplastics exposures. For example, it has been reported that Pocillopora damicornis did not ingest, but was attached by, microplastics at tentacles or mesenterial filaments, which could result in coral bleaching and tissue necrosis (Reichert et al., 2018) . These studies have revealed potential negative effects of microplastics on scleractinian corals; however, the detailed mechanism underlying the effects is not well understood.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: This study used P. damicornis as a model to fill the gap of understanding on detailed mechanisms of microplastic effects on scleractinian corals. P. damicornis belongs to the family Pocilloporidae, and is widely distributed in the tropical and subtropical areas of the Indian and Pacific Oceans. To understand the potential effects of microplastic exposure on symbiosis and physiology of this species, symbiont density and chlorophyll content, crucial enzyme activities, and transcriptomic profiles of the coral were investigated after an acute exposure to microplastics. Our results provide insights into molecular and biochemical level stress response that may precede or underpin physiological stress symptoms caused by microplastic pollution.
body_text.section: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT

body_text.text: Three P. damicornis colonies were collected from a fringing reef at a depth 1.5 m in Wenchang, China, and have been shown to harbor C clade Symbiodinium as the dominant genotype of endosymbionts (unpublished work). The branches in the colonies were split as nubbins, and these were attached on the plastic mesh plate located in the bottom of flow-through aquaria (ca. L) filled with natural seawater (26 °C). Cultures were illuminated with white and blue cool fluorescent bulbs (Philips T5HO Activiva Active 54 W) at a light intensity of 518 μmol photons m -2 s -1 in a 12 h/12 h light-dark cycle for one month to acclimatize in laboratory conditions.
body_text.section: Coral

body_text.text: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
body_text.section: Microplastic exposure

body_text.text: Polystyrene microplastics (diameter 1.0 µm, density 1.05 g cm -3 , Saierqun, China) with smooth surface were employed in the microplastic exposure experiment.
body_text.section: Microplastic exposure

body_text.text: Dispersed microplastics were added into the natural seawater to prepare a microplastic-containing seawater (50 mg L -1 , 9.0 × 10 10 particles L -1 ). Twenty-five coral nubbins were transferred immediately into the freshly prepared microplastic-containing seawater (3 tanks), which served as the microplastic group.
body_text.section: Microplastic exposure

body_text.text: Continuous gentle aeration was employed to avoid aggregations of microplastics.
body_text.section: Microplastic exposure

body_text.text: Another 25 nubbins were placed in tanks containing natural seawater as a control group (3 tanks). Coral nubbins were randomly sampled in the microplastic and control groups after 6, 12, and 24 h of incubation, and the rest of 10 nubbins was randomly sampled at 0 h. For metatranscriptome sequencing, 3 nubbins were sampled from each group after 12 h exposure, and immediately stored in liquid nitrogen. To measure the density and chlorophyll content of the endosymbionts as well as stress-related enzyme activities of the coral, 6 nubbins were sampled from each group after 0, 6, 12 and 24 h.
body_text.section: Microplastic exposure

body_text.text: The density variation of symbiotic zooxanthellae after acute microplastic exposure was measured following a previous method with a few modifications (Higuchi et al., 2008; Higuchi et al., 2015) . Briefly, coral tissues were homogenized in approximately 10 mL phosphate buffered saline (PBS, pH 7.4). Two-milliliter homogenates were then centrifuged to collect the supernatants for the determination of enzyme activities,
body_text.section: Density determination of symbiotic zooxanthellae

body_text.text: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
body_text.section: Density determination of symbiotic zooxanthellae

body_text.text: while the symbiotic zooxanthellae were resuspended and counted using a hemocytometer. The surface area of the nubbins was determined using the aluminum foil method (Johannes et al., 1970) . The symbiont density was defined as the number of symbiotic zooxanthellae per unit surface area of the coral nubbins (cells cm -2 ).
body_text.section: Density determination of symbiotic zooxanthellae

body_text.text: Chlorophyll content of symbiotic zooxanthellae was determined after acute microplastic exposure as previously reported (Hedouin et al., 2016) . Briefly, 2 mL homogenates were centrifuged at 2397 ×g, 4 ℃ for 10 min to obtain symbiotic zooxanthellae. The harvested zooxanthellae were resuspended in PBS, and centrifuged at 13812 ×g, 4 ℃ for 30 s. Chlorophyll a and c were extracted for 24 h at 4 ℃ in 2 mL of 100% acetone, followed by a centrifugation at 13812 ×g, ℃ for 30 s.
body_text.section: Measurement of chlorophyll content

body_text.text: The absorbance values of the extracts were measured at 630 and 663 nm. The total content of chlorophyll a+c 2 were computed according to the equations of Jeffrey and Humphrey (Jeffrey and Humphrey, 1975) . The total quantity of chlorophyll a+c 2 was divided by the number of symbionts to yield chlorophyll content (pg cell -1 ).
body_text.section: Measurement of chlorophyll content

body_text.text: manufacturer's recommendations. After the total enzyme activities were obtained, the concentration of total protein in the supernatant was quantified using BCA method (Zhou et al., 2018b) , and used to normalize the measured activities of SOD, CAT, AKP, and GST to U mg -1 protein.
body_text.section: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT

body_text.text: Phenoloxidase (PO) activity was detected using the method described by Palmer (Palmer et al., 2011) . Briefly, 20 µL supernatant was mixed with 65 µL PBS in the well of microplate (Costar). After the addition of µL of 10 mM L-DOPA (Sigma Aldrich, in PBS), the absorbance at 490 nm in each reaction well was measured every 5 min for 45 min using a microplate spectrophotometer (TECAN, infinite F50). The PO activity was defined as the change of absorbance (△OD 490 ) catalyzed by 1 mg supernatant protein in 1 min for the linear portion of the reaction curve, and expressed as △OD 490 mg -1 min -1 .
body_text.section: Activity assay of phenoloxidase

body_text.text: Coral nubbins were grinded and mixed with 1 mL Trizol reagent (Invitrogen). After centrifugation at 2397 ×g, 4 ℃ for 5 min to discard coral skeleton, total RNA was purified according to the described protocol (Stefanik et al., 2013) , and used to construct paired-end fragment libraries (2×150 bp). These transcriptome libraries were sequenced using the Illumina HiseqX platform in BGI (Shenzhen, China), and all raw sequencing reads were deposited in the SRA database under Accession No.
body_text.section: High-throughput sequencing of P. damicornis holobiont metatranscriptome

body_text.text: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT SRP133274.
body_text.section: High-throughput sequencing of P. damicornis holobiont metatranscriptome

body_text.text: Raw reads were filtered to obtain high-quality ones according to our previous study (Zhou et al., 2018a) . The obtained clean reads from six libraries were pooled to assemble the transcripts using the Trinity software (Grabherr et al., 2011) . Coral and zooxanthella transcripts were further separated through BLAST analysis. The genomes of coral Acropora digitifera and zooxanthella Symbiodinium minutum, Symbiodinium kawagutii, and Symbiodinium microadriaticum had been sequenced (Aranda et al., 2016; Lin et al., 2015; Shinzato et al., 2011; Shoguchi et al., 2013) , and their protein sequences were pooled and formatted as a BLAST database, to which our assembled transcripts were mapped using BLASTX (evalue = 1 × 10 -5 ).
body_text.section: Transcriptome assembly and separation of coral versus symbiont transcripts

body_text.text: Transcripts showing higher amino acid sequence similarity to the A. digitifera proteins were binned as P. damicornis transcripts; those showing higher similarity to Symbiodinium were regarded as Symbiodinium transcripts. These transcripts were used in the subsequent functional annotation and differential expression analysis (by reads mapping).
body_text.section: Transcriptome assembly and separation of coral versus symbiont transcripts

body_text.text: The filtered paired-end reads were mapped to the references constructed by the separated coral and zooxanthella transcripts using the HISAT2 software (Pertea et al., 2016) . Next, the differentially expressed genes between the microplastic and control
body_text.section: Identification and GO overrepresentation of differentially expressed genes

body_text.text: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
body_text.section: Identification and GO overrepresentation of differentially expressed genes

body_text.text: groups were identified (FDR < 0.05) using the obtained BAM files by means of StringTie and DESeq2 software (Love et al., 2014) , and binned into two groups including one significantly up-regulated and the other significantly down-regulated genes.
body_text.section: Identification and GO overrepresentation of differentially expressed genes

body_text.text: The identified coral and zooxanthella transcripts were translated in silico to proteins using TransDecoder v5.0.2 (http://transdecoder.github.io/), and annotated through functional categorization and GO term assignment, following the procedure of the Trinotate v3.1.1 (http://trinotate.github.io/). Overrepresented GO terms were analyzed for significantly up-regulated and down-regulated genes according the previous study (Zhou et al., 2018a) .
body_text.section: Identification and GO overrepresentation of differentially expressed genes

body_text.text: All data are presented as means ± standard deviation (SD) from biological replicates.
body_text.section: Statistical analysis

body_text.text: All of the data were subjected to two-way analysis of variance (two-way ANOVA) followed by multiple comparison (S-N-K) using SPSS v22.0 (SPSS Inc., Chicago, Illinois) to determine significant differences among different groups. Differences were considered significant at p < 0.05.
body_text.section: Statistical analysis

body_text.text: The density and chlorophyll content of zooxanthellae were determined in P. damicornis after acute microplastic exposure. We found no significant difference in
body_text.section: Symbiont density and chlorophyll content after microplastic exposure

body_text.text: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
body_text.section: Symbiont density and chlorophyll content after microplastic exposure

body_text.text: the density of zooxanthellae between the microplastic and control groups during the whole experimental period (Fig. 1A) . However, the chlorophyll content of zooxanthellae increased significantly after microplastic exposure. Chlorophyll content was highest at 12 h exposure (23.6 ± 5.71 pg cell -1 , p < 0.05), and returned to the background levels at 24 h (14.09 ± 2.14 pg cell -1 ) (Fig. 1B) .
body_text.section: Symbiont density and chlorophyll content after microplastic exposure

body_text.text: The SOD and CAT activities in the whole P. damicornis nubbins both showed an increase after the acute microplastic exposure. For SOD activity, significant increase was observed only at 6 h (204.2 U mg -1 , p < 0.05) of exposure ( Fig. 2A) . CAT activity in the microplastic group was significantly higher (171.3 U mg -1 , p < 0.05) after 12 h exposure, in comparison with those in the control group (Fig. 2B ). GST and AKP activities both decreased significantly after the acute microplastic exposure. The GST activity reached the lowest level at 24 h (28.1 U mg -1 , p < 0.05), which was significantly lower than those in the control group (Fig. 2C) . The AKP activities at 6 and 24 h (13.1 U mg -1 , 11.8 U mg -1 , p < 0.05) of the microplastic exposure were lower than those in the control group (Fig. 2D) . However, PO activity in the microplastic group showed no significant changes throughout the experiment, compared to those in the control group ( Fig. 2E) . (Table. 2).
body_text.section: Temporal activities of SOD, CAT, GST, AKP, and PO after microplastic exposure

body_text.text: Sequencing reads were mapped using HISAT2 software to the reference database constructed from our assembled and binned coral and zooxanthella transcripts. For all the six libraries, the mapped rates to the coral and zooxanthella transcripts ranged from 21.31 to 39.50% and from 43.22 to 64.14%, respectively (Table 1) . The DESeq2 software further used the counts of mapped reads in each gene to identify differentially expressed genes (Tables S1, S2). The analysis revealed 349 and 107 differentially expressed genes in the scleractinian coral and symbiotic zooxanthellae, Tables S3, S4 ). A total of 134 genes were significantly up-regulated and significantly down-regulated for the coral, while correspondingly 12 and 95 zooxanthella genes were significantly up-regulated and down-regulated, respectively.
body_text.section: Transcriptomic responses of coral and zooxanthella symbionts to microplastic exposure

body_text.text: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT respectively (
body_text.section: Transcriptomic responses of coral and zooxanthella symbionts to microplastic exposure

body_text.text: For the 135 significantly up-regulated coral genes, they were mainly enriched in 11 GO terms (Table S5 , Fig. 3 ). These GO terms were primarily related to stress response, zymogen granule and JNK signal pathway. A total of 25 overrepresented GO terms were detected from the 216 significantly down-regulated coral genes (Table S6 , Fig.   4 ). These GO terms were mainly involved in sterol transport and the EGF-ERK1/2 signal pathway. In contrast, no overrepresented GO term was found for the significantly up-regulated and down-regulated zooxanthella genes. The up-regulated genes included persulfide dioxygenase and haloacid dehalogenase-like hydrolase domain-containing protein 3, among others (Table S7 ). The down-regulated genes were dominantly hypothetical proteins but also included ubiquitin protein ligase HERC1, chloroplastic pentatricopetide repeat-containing protein, and 1,3-beta-glucan synthase component bgs3, among others (Table S8 ).
body_text.section: Transcriptomic responses of coral and zooxanthella symbionts to microplastic exposure

body_text.text: Microplastic pollution is currently considered a serious hazard to the marine environment (Imhof et al., 2017) , and can contribute to coral bleaching and necrosis (Reichert et al., 2018) . In the present study, no significant changes were observed in the symbiont density after microplastic exposure, while its chlorophyll content increased significantly at 12 h. In the host coral P. damicornis, the activities of SOD
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: and CAT underwent significant increases, whereas GST and AKP significant decreases. Transcriptomic analysis further revealed the regulation of coral stress response, zymogen granule, JNK signal pathway, sterol transport, and EGF-ERK1/2 signal pathway.
body_text.section: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT

body_text.text: The density and chlorophyll content of zooxanthellae was determined to understand the susceptibility of coral-zooxanthella symbiosis to acute microplastic exposure. The density of zooxanthellae did not change significantly during the 24 h exposure period to microplastics, demonstrating that the short-term microplastic exposure is not likely to impair the symbiotic relationship between zooxanthellae and P. damicornis. On the contrary, the chlorophyll content of zooxanthellae increased significantly at 12 h after microplastic exposure, compared to that in the control group. This is different from the reports that microplastics had negative effects on chlorophyll content and photosynthetic efficiency of free-living marine microalgae (Long et al., 2017; Zhang et al., 2017) . The inconsistency might be because in our case most of the microplastics attached to the coral (Reichert et al., 2018) . The attachment to the coral tissue likely blocked out some of the light that would otherwise reach the endosymbiotic zooxanthellae. Increased chlorophyll content is a common response in algae to reduction of light availability (Falkowski, 1980) . Furthermore, few differentially expressed genes were observed for the symbiotic zooxanthellae after the acute exposure to microplastics, with no GO terms being overrepresented for the differentially expressed genes. Two of the up-regulated genes, persulfide dioxygenase
body_text.section: Mild impact of acute microplastic exposure on symbiosis

body_text.text: and haloacid dehalogenase-like hydrolase domain-containing protein 3, have homologs in humans that function to prevent sulfide and general detoxification.
body_text.section: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT

body_text.text: Persulfide dioxygenase functions in oxidizing sulfide to prevent sulfide toxicity (Kabil and Banerjee, 2012) , and haloacid dehalogenase belongs to a superfamily of phosphorus-related enzymes, the function of which ranges from amino acid synthesis to detoxification (Carepo et al., 2004) . Whether their up-regulation under microplastic exposure indicates heightened capacity to counter the potential cytotoxic effects of the microplastics is worth further exploring in the future. All these results suggest that acute microplastic stress disturbed, but did not disrupt, the symbiosis between zooxanthellae and P. damicornis over a short term, although the down-regulation of 1,3-beta-glucan synthase can potentially cause some change in host pattern recognition (Lin et al. 2015) .
body_text.section: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT

body_text.text: Our analysis of the transcriptomes of P. damicornis at 12 h of acute microplastic exposure revealed a total of 134 significantly up-regulated genes and 215 significantly down-regulated coral genes. Further inspection of their GO term enrichment indicated that the significantly up-regulated genes were mainly related to stress response, zymogen granule and JNK signal pathway. The GO term overrepresentation related to stress response has also been observed in P. damicornis subjected to cadmium and ammonium stress (Yuan et al., 2017; Zhou et al., 2018a) , suggesting that the exposure
body_text.section: Stress response at molecular and biochemical levels, and evidence of immune and detoxification depression in the coral caused by acute microplastic exposure

body_text.text: of microplastics might have activated the general stress response mechanism in this scleractinian coral. Meanwhile, the acute microplastic stress seemed to have activated the JNK signal pathway, because 4 GO terms related to this pathway were overrepresented by the significantly up-regulated genes. It has been reported in monogonont rotifer B. koreanus that microplastic stress can activate the JNK signal pathway through protein phosphorylation (Jeong et al., 2016) . Besides, it is intriguing to note the up-regulation of zymogen, a protected storage of enzymes, which are often precursors of digestive enzymes that need to be activated by other enzymes for their functions. The up-regulation of this gene suggests that the microplastic-exposed coral might respond in producing more of these digestive enzymes for defense while preventing digesting their own cellular components. Furthermore, the overrepresented GO terms for significantly down-regulated genes were mainly related to the EGF-ERK1/2 signal pathway and sterol transport. As both JNK and EGF-ERK1/2 signal pathways showed response at the transcriptional level in the present study, it is possible that microplastics may function as an environmental hormone to modulate various coral physiological activities, for instance through zymogen activation, and basal metabolism in P. damicornis.
body_text.section: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT

body_text.text: The most crucial physiological processes of stress response are anti-oxidative stress, detoxification and immune response for corals that live in shallow tropical/tropical waters (Weis, 2008) . We monitored several parameters of these processes to shed light on the short-term effects of acute microplastic stress on P. damicornis. SOD and CAT are the main antioxidases in the coral redox system (Levy et al., 2006) , and their M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT significant increase in the microplastic-exposed group at some point of the microplastic exposure suggests that the acute microplastic stress could transiently induce the antioxidant capacity of P. damicornis. Similar transient changes of antioxidase activities were also observed in other corals suffering from environmental stress (Levy et al., 2006; Soriano-Santiago et al., 2013) . In turn, these results suggest elevated production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) during microplastic stress, because the elevated ROS level resulting from a high temperature, air exposure or other stress conditions has been shown to induce the antioxidase gene expressions and activities in scleractinian corals (Levy et al., 2006; Teixeira et al., 2013; Yakovleva et al., 2004) . Furthermore, this is consistent with our transcriptomic results showing that the exposure of microplastics activated stress response in P. damicornis. Because excessive oxidative stress is considered the main inducer of the collapse of coral-zooxanthella symbiosis (Downs et al., 2002; Lesser, 1997) , the increase of SOD and CAT activities would be important for maintaining the stability of the symbiosis after acute microplastic stress.
body_text.section: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT

body_text.text: As a crucial phase II metabolic enzymes in the detoxification process of all eukaryotes (Nicosia et al., 2014) , GST activity was also determined over the course of microplastic exposure. It was observed that the GST activity decreased significantly at 24 h after the exposure, suggesting that acute microplastic exposure could repress the detoxification system in P. damicornis. The decline of GST activity might have been mediated through the JNK and ERK signal pathways discussed earlier, since the modulation of the phase II detoxification enzyme expression by JNK and ERK
body_text.section: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT

body_text.text: pathways have been observed in other animals (Chang et al., 2010; Gu et al., 2011) .
body_text.section: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT

body_text.text: The suppression of the detoxification system is clearly unfavorable for the survival of scleractinian corals and the maintenance of coral-zooxanthella symbiosis under microplastic stress. Microplastics can carry chemicals of small molecular sizes, such as hydrophobic chemicals and additives, which can penetrate into cells and cause severe toxic effects on organisms (Teuten et al., 2009) . Therefore, the suppression of the detoxification system owing to the decline of GST activity might increase the toxic effects of any attached chemicals on P. damicornis exposed to microplastics.
body_text.section: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT

body_text.text: The immune system is a host defense system responsible for the recognition and clearance of pathogenic organisms or materials. The immune function of PO and AKP had been demonstrated in scleractinian corals (Godinot et al., 2013; Palmer et al., 2011) , and therefore the activities of PO and AKP were also investigated under acute microplastic exposure. The PO activities did not change significantly, while the AKP activities underwent significant decreases suggesting that microplastic-induced stress might compromise the immune system in P. damicornis, possibly through the regulation of JNK and ERK signal pathways. The immune system of scleractinian corals defends against pathogenic organisms and the stabilization of symbiotic zooxanthellae (Palmer et al., 2010) . The suppression of the immune system could increase the susceptibility of scleractinian corals to pathogenic microorganisms and bleaching, because the infection of pathogenic microorganisms such as Vibrio coralliilyticus could result in the expulsion of symbiotic zooxanthellae and the bleaching of the scleractinian coral P. damicornis (Ben-Haim et al., 2003) . These
body_text.section: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT

body_text.text: results collectively suggest that short-term exposure to high concentrations of microplastics can trigger a stress response in the coral host, and regulate the JNK and ERK signal pathways to repress the detoxification and immune system. Short-term exposure to high concentrations of microplastics has the potential to cause negative effects on the health of coral-zooxanthella symbiont in the scleractinian coral P. damicornis even though it did not seem to cause significant stress in the zooxanthellae and collapse of the coral-zooxanthella symbiosis.
body_text.section: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT

body_text.text: In the present study, 50 mg L -1 microplastics was employed to treat the coral, which was within the range of those used in other reports on scleractinian corals (24-395 mg L -1 ) (Allen et al., 2017; Hall et al., 2015; Reichert et al., 2018) . However, the concentration was equivalent to an abundance of 9.0 × 10 10 particles L -1 , substantially higher than that observed in natural scenarios (e.g. 8 particles L -1 in Swedish sea area (Auta et al., 2017; Wright et al., 2013 ). The effective microplastic particle still needs to be further determined through attenuated total reflectance Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (Kroon et al., 2018) ; however, the concentration used in the present study was still markedly higher than that in natural coral reefs. The high particle abundance of microplastics was employed in the acute exposure to ensure measurable cytological, physiological and transcriptomic responses of both the coral and the endosymbiont. The obtained results suggest that acute exposure to high concentrations of microplastics can activate the stress response of the scleractinian coral P. damicornis, and repress its detoxification and immune system through the JNK and ERK signal pathways, despite the minimal impact on the abundance and M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT major photosynthate translocation transporters of the symbiont in the short term.
body_text.section: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT

body_text.text: Based on our result, it is apparent that short-term exposure to realistic concentrations of microplastics in the ocean will unlikely cause breakdown of symbiosis between P. damicornis and its algal endosymbionts. However, long-term exposure to lower concentrations still needs to be investigated. Besides, effects of the acute exposure on other coral species also remain to be examined. Overrepresented GO terms of the 134 significantly up-regulated coral genes in the microplastic group at 12 h after acute microplastic exposure. A total of 11 GO terms were found overrepresented for these significantly up-regulated genes. "Ref"
body_text.section: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT

body_text.text: A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
body_text.section: M A N U S C R I P T

body_text.text: refers to the proportion of genes functionally assigned a GO term out of all coral genes existing in the reference transcriptome, while "test" refers to the proportion of genes assigned to that GO term out of the 134 significantly up-regulated genes.
body_text.section: M A N U S C R I P T

back_matter.text: The authors were grateful to all of the laboratory members for their continuous technical advice and helpful discussions. Z.Z. gratefully acknowledges the financial support from China Scholarship Council 201708460042

FIGREF0.text: six metatranscriptome libraries of P. damicornis were sequenced to quantitatively compare the gene expression profiles, including three libraries in the microplastic group and three libraries in the control group. A total of 199,227,830 paired-end reads of 2×150 bp in length were obtained, with similar amounts of data from each sample (Table. 1). The assembling de novo yielded a total of 633,120 transcripts (N50 = 1999 bp), corresponding to 256,388 genes (N50 = 1542 bp). Furthermore, the encoded proteins of 156,466 transcripts (38,951 genes, transcript N50 = 3021 bp, gene N50 = 3136 bp) shared higher homology with A. digitifera, and were therefore defined as P. damicornis transcripts. Likewise, 158,519 transcripts (48,935 genes, transcript N50 = 2064 bp, gene N50 = bp) were regarded as the transcripts of the symbiont

FIGREF2.text: Density and chlorophyll content variation of the symbiotic zooxanthellae in Pocillopora damicornis after acute microplastic exposure. Data points represent means and error bars represent standard deviations (N = 6). Asterisks depict significant differences between the microplastic and control groups (p < 0.05).

FIGREF3.text: Temporal patterns of SOD, CAT, GST, AKP and PO activities in Pocillopora damicornis in the acute microplastic exposure experiment. (A) Superoxide dismutase (SOD). (B) Catalase (CAT). (C) glutathione S-transferase (GST). (D) alkaline phosphatase (AKP). (E) phenoloxidase (PO). Data points represent means and error bars represent standard deviations (N = 6). Asterisks depict significant differences between the microplastic and control groups (p < 0.05).

FIGREF4.text: Fig 3. Overrepresented GO terms of the 134 significantly up-regulated coral genes in

FIGREF5.text: Overrepresented GO terms of the 215 significantly down-regulated coral genes in the microplastic group at 12 h after acute microplastic exposure. A total of 25 GO terms were overrepresented for these significantly down-regulated genes. "Ref" refers to the proportion of genes functionally assigned to a GO term out of all coral genes existing in the reference transcriptome, while "test" refers to the proportion of genes M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT assigned to that GO term out of the 215 significantly down-regulated genes.
